Weekly Appreciation No.25.DEMOBILISATION,The follQWing table shews tho progress ef-demobilisation?-iRAHCH, ' ' ' 1 Strength at Kov.ll.1918. Ho. demobills-ed week ending June 19, 1919. Off, O.R..KAVY .A.P. 35,419 171,900 27,100 375,130 3,544,000 251,000 819 1,562 1,079 3,102 2fc,993 828 14,122 93,548 15,190 208,803 2,483,132 180,860 11,297 21,052 5,036 30,734 * 7,058pTAL. 234,419 4,170,130 3,460 33,923 122,860 2,886,795 37,385 i* This figure has net yet been supplied by the far Office. In addition, 424 Officers and 26,585 Other Ranks have sen demobilised from Women's Corps? from a strength of 2,040 Officers id 77,200 Other Ranks.Training cf Disabled Sailors and Soldiers. At the 18th June, 11,252 Disabled Sailers^ and Soldiers were ^ing trained for various Trades and Professions, and 16,378 had been scharged Trained.Unemployment.The number of 0ut-of-*7ork Donation Policies remaining lodged I the 13th June was 664,829, as compared with 710,875 on the 6th June, fall of 46,046 for the week. All classes if Policies share in this 11, as followst-H .11. Forces, ken, Women.Total:Reduction. 6,855 49.6,884Civilians.Hen, Boys, Women, Girls,Reductions.12,1831,066 23,6431,97039,162 E,IyI,Forces Policies loosed have now fallen continuously for five weeks, the total reduction since the 9th Kay being 51,191, or 7,6 per cent.Since the 2nd Kay, when the number of Policies lodged reached the maximum. Civilian Policies lodged have fallen by 403,872, or 58 per cent. Women's Policios alone have fallen by 276,512, or 65.3 per cent.The figures of Policies lodged are set out in extensc in Appendix 1.The Industrial Analysis set out in Appendix 2 shews an improvement in all industries except Agriculture, where the in-crease of 100 Is wholly among demobilised menj and Textiles-"Other"-which includes Linen, Silk and Jute, as well as dyeing, printing, etc. This group shews an increase of 3,650. The improvement in the Cotton Industry is'noticeable. Donation is no longer paid under the Cotton Control Board Scheme, and, therefore, the figure shewn is a true reflex of whole-time unemployment in the Industry.Short Time.Appendix 3 gives an analysis Qf the persons on Short Time who were drawing Donation up to the 6th June. The number -82,558-is lower by 8,220 than the figure for the previous week. The im-provement ib almost solely due to the decrease in Short Time in the Textile Industries in Great Britain. The amount of Short Time in the Irish Linen Industry is further accentuated, the Short-Timers drawing donation rising by 1,294 to 47,004, or 58 percent Of the total number of persons on Short Time,Av C ,' G5DDES, mtsiploymeht DOHaTIOH POLICIES LODGED--f ' -- - -....... -f i f i t ---------- T i i i i ! j j .
